Program Goals. IAs can be a viable case resolution for many delinquent accounts. By following the direction in this IRM section, employees can identify proper procedures for completing IA actions for cases with special circum-

IAs are arrangements by which the Internal Revenue Service allows taxpayers to pay liabilities over time. Taxpayers should be encouraged to pay the liability in full to avoid the costs of an IA, which include a user fee, accrual of penalties and interest, and the possible ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL). If full payment cannot be achieved by the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to pay, a Partial Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA) may be granted. During the course of IAs, penalties and interest continue to accrue. Generally, no levies may be served while an IA is pending, in effect, or for
-days following rejection or termination and the appeal period if the rejection or termination is timely appealed.

IAs are arrangements by which the Internal Revenue Service allows taxpayers to pay liabilities over time. Taxpayers should be encouraged to pay the liability in full to avoid the costs of an IA, which include a user fee, accrual of and interest, and the possible ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL). If full payment cannot be achieved by the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to pay, a Partial Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA) may be granted. During the course of IAs, penalties and interest continue to accrue. Generally, no levies may be served while an IA is pending, in effect, or for 30-days following rejection or termination and the appeal period if the rejection or termination is timely appealed.

) The Director, Collection Policy is the executive responsible for the policies procedures related to the IA program. They are responsible for overseeing program coordination for ﬁeld collection personnel related to the IA (
) The program manager, Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) is responsible development and delivery policies, procedures and practices within the IA program. (
) Field collection group managers and territory managers are responsible for ensuring the guidance and procedures described in this IRM are complied with. (
) Collection employees are responsible for following the guidance provided in the IRM when processing cases. (

) Program Reports: a. Monthly IA Trend Report. Sourced from Collection Activity Report CRA generates and reviews a monthly IA trend report that captures on the various types of IAs and compares year-over-year data on IA inventory levels, the number of IAs initiated, default rates, full pay and dollars collected. Any anomalies are identiﬁed and researched for potential causes. Negative trends are identiﬁed and causes (

) Program Reviews: a. Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) will conduct ad hoc IA program reviews as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements, address TIGTA/GAO ﬁndings, and evaluate any trends that appear. b. Managers, leads, and On the Job Instructors (OJIs) use the Quality Review System (EQRS)/National Quality Review System Data Collection Instrument (DCI) to input case reviews. EQRS is used evaluate employee performance and provide feedback and NQRS reviews samples of closed work to measure compliance with IRM standards and provide organizational feedback regarding compliance. NQRS data is used to report the official organizational business results. c. Operational reviews are conducted by the territory manager and area director annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ministrative and compliance requirements.

The Integrated Collection System (ICS) is a case management system that supports SBSE revenue officers (ROs) in working delinquent tax cases. In every case, the ﬁle must show that the disposition method selected is consis- tent with the facts outlined in the case, the IRM, and other official guidance. Certain actions taken by ICS users generate systemic approval requests to manager. All Non-Streamlined Installment Agreement (NSIA) case dispositions require managerial approval.

Delinquent Taxes: balance due, Automatic Collection Systems (ACS) balance due accounts and/or notice status accounts Accrued Taxes: unassessed amounts due on returns, missed estimated tax payments or undeposited FTDs as of the date of contact Current Taxes: Federal Tax Deposits (FTDs) and estimated (ES) tax payments that become due after the date of contact

For certain liabilities assessed in the name and EIN of an LLC, different Single Member Owners (SMOs) may be liable for separate tax periods assessed in the same name and EIN. See IRM

, Collecting from Limited Liability Companies . If multiple SMOs are liable for different tax periods assessed in the same name and EIN separate IAs would be required for each taxpayer and should be established using the Manually Monitored procedures in IRM
, Manually Monitored Installment Agreements (MMIA).

Married taxpayers who ﬁle joint tax returns are each responsible for all due related to the jointly ﬁled returns, even if they later divorce and even if divorce decree or marital settlement agreement states that one taxpayer will be responsible, in full or in part, for amounts due on previously ﬁled returns. This means the IRS can collect all the taxes due from either regardless of the income either taxpayer earned. If one of the taxpayers requests separate treatment from his or her spouse under IRC
, and one taxpayer wishes to enter into an IA, the account must be “mirrored” for each joint period(s). See IRM
, for information about relief from joint several liability under IRC

account for each spouse. The mirroring effect allows the IRS to treat each taxpayer separately and the rights of both taxpayers are protected. . If the spouse who does not request IRC
relief from the liability the requesting spouse requests an IA, and there is an unreversed TC

Married taxpayers who ﬁle joint tax returns are each responsible for all taxes due related to the jointly ﬁled returns, even if they later divorce and even if a divorce decree or marital settlement agreement states that one taxpayer alone will be responsible, in full or in part, for amounts due on previously ﬁled joint returns. This means the IRS can collect all the taxes due from either taxpayer, regardless of the income either taxpayer earned. If one of the taxpayers requests separate treatment from his or her spouse under IRC
, and only one taxpayer wishes to enter into an IA, the account must be “mirrored” for each joint period(s). See IRM
, for information about relief from joint and several liability under IRC

When a request to Withdraw an IA has been received, complete Form 14425 , Withdrawal of Request for Installment Agreement, and document ICS:

If Then The request is received during Document ICS history of: telephone or face-to-face • Name in Signature contact... • Date Signed • Reason for the Withdrawal The request is received with cor- • Document ICS history respondence... showing who signed, the date, and the reason for the withdrawal request.
Note: If, after a verbal request for withdrawal, written conﬁrmation is not received, document the case ﬁle as to how the request for withdrawal occurred.
Verbal requests are effective ﬁve (
) calendar days from the day they are received unless a written conﬁrmation of a verbal request is received within ﬁve (

) day period. Taxpayers should be advised that by withdrawing their request, appeal rights with respect to that pending IA are extinguished, however, taxpayers can propose a new IA at any time. Cases received with a pending IA indicator must be dealt with even if the is resolved without either approving or rejecting the IA. Other situations a Withdrawal of IA request should be addressed, include full payment, OIC, CNC, CDP, and Bankruptcy. Requests for IAs are considered withdrawn withdrawals are effective): a. upon receipt of written requests for withdrawal, or b. ﬁve (

) calendar days after a verbal request for withdrawal. Withdrawals should not be solicited by contact employees, but questions be asked to clarify misunderstanding of taxpayers’ statements. Request input of TC

) For background information on Restitution Based Assessments (RBAs) - IRM
, Restitution Based Assessments. Installment (
) ROs may receive an OI from an APL or a balance due module on conduct a ﬁeld investigation on a RBA. and (
) Civil assessments with associated RBAs may be received in any Civil work stream (Field, Campus, Automated Collection System) but may only - Overview worked by ROs. (

) IAs for RBAs can only be considered if the proposed IA will result in the payment of the RBA within the terms of the IA and by the CSED. Any civil assessment should be included in the IA, even if the payment won’t result in full payment of those civil assessments. CCP will determine the IA is a PPIA once the RBAs are paid in full. (
) IAs that include RBAs should only be established by ROs. If there is an Conditions of Probation (COP) case, the RO should coordinate the ment of the IA with the APL. (

) In the event the taxpayer’s ability to pay will not result in the full payment the RBA, MMIAs for civil assessments (including PPIAs) can be exclusive of RBA assessments (that is, the RBA is not included as part of IA) in cases where the taxpayer’s income/expense analysis shows an pay above the allowable expenses (which will include the court ordered tion payment). ) Pending IA status - IA proposals for RBAs that do not provide for the full payment of the RBAs by the CSED cannot be considered as a pending IA the RBA modules. If there are associated civil assessments for which the IA proposal can be considered, exclusive of the RBA, those modules should a TC
AC
input if pending IA requirements are met and the IA cannot be approved immediately. (

) Computing Payment Amount - Standard ﬁnancial analysis will be conducted determine the appropriate monthly payment amount. Taxpayers will make any court ordered restitution payments directly to the courts, and ance with the court ordered payments will be listed as an additional of the IA. This payment will be considered an allowable expense when mining the taxpayer’s ability to make monthly payments. See IRM , Other Expenses, regarding deduction of court-ordered payments as expenses. (

) Rejection Issues - The ICS history should clearly indicate the basis for the rejection and clearly identify cases that are rejected based on the fact that proposed payment as determined by ﬁnancial analysis will not satisfy the by the CSED. Rejection of an IA that includes a RBA requires concurrence from the Independent Administrative Reviewer. (
) If accepted, IAs that include RBAs require managerial approval and will be sent to CCP as a MMIA. (

) Posting of Payments - Payments on IAs that include both RBAs and civil sessments should be posted to the RBAs until fully paid and then in the interest of the government for the civil assessments. Payments on MMIAs exclude RBAs will be posted to the civil assessments in the best interest of government. (

) The APL will be familiar with the court order and COP. The APL will be able advise the RO regarding appropriate actions to take and will facilitate tion with the DOJ Financial Litigation Units when necessary. RBA cases will not be worked by Campus Collection operations. APLs receiving contacts Field or Campus Collection employees about RBA modules or related ments should issue an OI to the appropriate Field Area group for if not already assigned. (
) Payments received by Field Collection employees will be posted using
2200. Once assigned, the Field will Close the Advisory OI and work the balance due module(s) and related modules, if any.

Payments received by Field Collection employees will be posted using estab- lished Designated Payment Codes (DPC). Payments received as a result of administrative collection action may be applied in the government’s best interest. Court ordered restitution payments made to the clerk of court will continue to be sent by the court to Kansas City Submission Processing where they will be posted using DPC
SB/SE Campus Compliance Services will cross reference any balance due payments to ensure the full amount of the restitution is only collected once and is not overpaid.
